levels package

Submodules

levels.greensleeves module

This file controls our greensleeves level. It contains all information for this level to run including audio detection and filtering, notes to be played, animations for this level, background generation, pause menu, and main loop to keep the level running.

levels.greensleeves.audio_callback(in_data, frame_count, time_info, status)[source]

A callback function for real-time audio processing, typically used with a PyAudio stream.

This function is called by PyAudio whenever new audio data is available. It processes the audio data by applying a bandpass filter, analyzes it to extract pitch information, and then predicts the frequency, confidence, and amplitude. It also handles exceptions by catching them and printing an error message.

Parameters:

  • in_data (bytes) – The buffer of audio data provided by PyAudio.

  • frame_count (int) – The number of frames in the buffer.

  • time_info (dict) – A dictionary containing timing information.

  • status (int) – Status flag indicating if there are any errors or special conditions.

Returns:

A tuple containing the original audio data buffer and a flag indicating whether the stream should continue.

Return type:

tuple

levels.greensleeves.butter_bandpass_filter(data, lowcut, highcut, sr, order=5)[source]

Apply a Butterworth bandpass filter to given one-dimensional data.

This function uses a digital bandpass filter design to filter the provided data. The Butterworth filter is a type of signal processing filter designed to have a flat frequency response in the passband.

Parameters:

  • data (array_like) – The input signal to be filtered.

  • lowcut (float) – The lower frequency boundary of the passband (Hz).

  • highcut (float) – The upper frequency boundary of the passband (Hz).

  • sr (int) – The sampling rate of the data (Hz).

  • order (int, optional) – The order of the filter. Higher order means a sharper frequency cutoff, but the filter will also be slower to execute. The default is 5.

Returns:

y – The filtered output with the same shape as data.

Return type:

ndarray

levels.greensleeves.create_graph(index_array, accuracy_array, totnote)[source]

Creates a line graph representing accuracy over a range of indices and saves it as an image.

This function uses a subprocess to run a Python script that generates a graph using matplotlib. This method ensures that the creation of the graph does not disrupt the GUI’s window size. The graph is saved to a predefined directory (assets/images/tempgraphs/) as graphy.png.

Parameters:

  • index_array (list of int) – A list of indices corresponding to some sequence of measurements or evaluations.

  • accuracy_array (list of float) – A list of accuracy measurements corresponding to the indices in index_array.

  • totnote (int) – The maximum value on the x-axis, representing the total number of observations.

levels.greensleeves.midi_number_to_pitch(midi_number)[source]

Convert a MIDI note number to its corresponding pitch name with octave.

This function utilizes the music21 library to convert MIDI note numbers into human-readable pitch names, including the octave. The music21 library’s Note object is used to handle the conversion.

Parameters:

midi_number (int) – The MIDI number that represents a specific pitch. MIDI numbers range from 0 to 127, where 60 corresponds to Middle C (C4).

Returns:

The pitch name with octave, as a string. For example, a midi_number of 60 will return ‘C4’.

Return type:

str

levels.greensleeves.start()[source]
